0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Radionuclide hepatobiliary study: (average patient, 70 kg) non-jaundiced, 37 to 185 megabecquerels (1 to 5 millicuries) by slow IV; if a second dose is required allow at least 24 hours between doses; if the gallbladder is not visualized within the first 60 minutes of imaging, single-dose morphine 0.04 mg/kg IV over 3 minutes may be given to shorten the time required for visualization, patency of the bile duct must be confirmed prior to morphine administration
  • Radionuclide hepatobiliary study: (average patient, 70 kg) serum bilirubin greater than 5 mg/dL, 111 to 296 megabecquerels (3 to 8 millicuries) by slow IV; if a second dose is required allow at least 24 hours between doses; if the gallbladder is not visualized within the first 60 minutes of imaging, single-dose morphine 0.04 mg/kg IV over 3 minutes may be given to shorten the time required for visualization, patency of the bile duct must be confirmed prior to morphine administration

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and effectiveness have not been established in children

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• allergic reactions may occur
  • biliary colic; morphine augmentation may increase patient discomfort
  • false positive results may occur with trauma, intercurrent disease, use of total parenteral nutrition, and nothing by mouth status
  • morphine augmentation may be associated with respiratory depression and/or postural syncope
  • patency of the common duct should be clearly evident prior to administration of morphine
  • radiopharmaceutical; handle with care, maintain adequate shielding of final preparation, and use safety measures to reduce radiation exposure to personnel and patient

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• AAP: Radioactive compounds that require temporary cessation of breastfeeding.
  • WHO: Avoid breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk has been demonstrated.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Technetium Tc 99m disofenin is an iminodiacetic acid (IDA) derivative that binds to plasma proteins (mainly albumin) for diagnosis or exclusion of acute cholecystitis. In the liver, in the space of Disse, technetium Tc 99m disofenin becomes dissociated from the proteins and enters the hepatocyte by a mechanism similar to that of serum bilirubin. Technetium Tc 99m disofenin traverses the hepatocyte un-metabolized and enters the bile canaliculi. Flow beyond the canaliculi is influenced, to a large extent, by the tone of the sphincter of Oddi and the patency of the bile ducts. Clear visualization of the gallbladder and intestines with technetium Tc 99m disofenin demonstrates hepatobiliary tract patency

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • write the estimated activity, date, and time of preparation on the space provided on the label and attach to the neck of the vial
  • water proof gloves should be worn during preparation
  • add 4 to 5 mL of Sodium Pertechnetate TC 99m to the reaction in a suitable radiation shield
  • use only preservative free sodium chloride injection for dilution
  • do not introduce air into the vial during reconstitution
  • after reconstitution place radiation shield on the vial, swirl contents, and let stand for 4 minutes
  • assay the product with a suitable dose calibrator
  • maintain adequate shielding during the life of the product and use dose within 6 hours of preparation

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: no specific monitoring has been determined

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause itching at the injection site which may progress to erythema multiforme.
  • Instruct patient to fast, preferably for 4 hours prior to administration/imaging; otherwise false positives (non-visualization) may result.
